Intercollegiate Relays Are Stellar Attractions. Connolly
The Johns Hopkins Publicity
Proves Star of Meet, Winning Open Mile

Board has launched its campaign
to bring the undergraduate school
more into the eye of the public.
Last week the board met and decided that the first article should
be sent out before the Fifth Regiment games. Due to the nearness
of the meet, it was thought advisable to make it the sole subject
of this first drive. Three separate
copies were written, one for the
big Eastern newspapers, one for
the larger state papers, and one for
college publications.
About three hundred form letters
were sent out last week—the
majority going to colleges that
are competing in the games. These
letters enumerated the more important collegiate relays and also the
names of noted athletes who will
be entered in this meet. So far
these letters have been favorably
received and have been published in
a number of papers, including all
of the New York dailies.
It was planned to give the Fifth
Regiment meet especial publicity
in the Washington papers, so that
as many Washingtonians as possible could take advantage of the special cars that ran on Saturday to
attend the games. The fact that
so many Washington schools are
entered shoulll greatly increase the
ihterest.
Much interest is being shown in
the Publicity Board by the students. At a meeting held Monday,
twenty new candidates entered
competition for places on the board.
The enthusiasm of these candidates
was great and excellent results are
expected. .Due to the fact that there
were a large number of Sophomores and Juniors among these
candidates, there will be enough
men of ability to carry on the work
next year.
The board is receiving financial
support from the Varsity Club and
the Student Council. The kindness
of Major Garey and the military
department has made possible much
more extensive work than would
otherwise have been possible. All
o f the copy was typewritten and
mimeographed without expense by
the military department.
As soon as the organization has
been fully completed, it will be possible to extend the range of action
of the board and the results will
become more pronounced.

HOPKINS WINS SOUTH ing in the fifteenth , annual Johns
ATLANTIC MILE RELAY Hopkins-Fifth Regiment Games,
Black and ,Blue Finishes With Wide
with a team which was lacking in
Margin. Medley Team Conquers Carnegie.

In the final event of the evening
the Johns Hopkins mile relay quartet proved that its performance a
week previous at New York was
no flash in the pan, when it triumphed over Virginia and Washing and Lee for the South Atlantic
title. This race was one of the features of the evening, and it came as
a pleasing ending to a program of
stellar track events. The Black
and Blue team was composed of
Thomson, Norwood; Skinner and
Edwards, all of whom had been
kept out of other competition and
primed for their event.
Captain Joe Thompson started
for Hopkins and finished even with
his Virginia man. By fine passing
of the baton, Randy Norwood, running second, managed to grab the
lead on the turn, which he increased to over ten feet before
handing the stick to Bob Skinner.
Bob made a name for himself when
he walked away from the Virginia
man. This he did, not in one sprint,
but by consistent and evenly
timed running. Once he had safely
passed the baton to Ridge Edwards;
the Hopkins rooters relaxed their
tensioned fists, for they knew that
only by a miracle could the latter
be headed. Ridge maintained his
team's lead all the way and if
pushed he could probably have lowered the time considerably. Virginia had second all the way, and
the Generals took third.
The Hopkins medley relay team
also came in for its share of the
glory when it trounced Carnegie
Tech by a wide margin. Clarke
ran first for Hopkins and opened
up a lead that was never increased
/
8 mile grind.
throughout the 17
Dorcus ran the quarter and proved
himself to be another star at that
distance. When he passed the stick
to Sommerville it was with a lead
large enough to foretell the ultimate victory. "Sommy" ran a pretty race and when he gave "Verne"
Booth a lead of about sixty yards
it was just a question of how decisive the victory would be. The
lanky Hopkins miler took things
easy and held the same lead
throughout.
Another feature of the meet,
from a Hopkins standpoint, was
the half-mile interfraternity relay.
This race had stirred up much
friendly rivalry between the different societies and it was a thriller
throughout. First one and then another team flashed into the lead.
Spills were numerous and excitement high at all stages. Marchetti,
anchor man for Kappa Sigma,
finally breezed down the last
straightaway with a comfortable
lead over Middleton, of Alpha Delta Phi. Kappa Alpha finished third.
In the open events only a few
of the Hopkins stars were entered,
most of them being saved for spe-

neither quantity nor quality, easily
captured the team trophy for open
events with a score three times as
great as its nearest competitor, Virginia. With such stars as Le Gendre, Connolly, Kinally, Davis, Shallott, Marsters, Tupar, Brooks,
Gaffey, Brewster, Vokman, Fenney and others, the Washingtonians
presented an array of talent that
was not approached by any other
college.
The shot which started the first
heat of the 100-yard dash was fired
at 7:30, and from that time until
12:20 the track was kept warm almost continuously by the pounding
o; hundreds of feet. After many
preliminaries and semi-finals, this
event was finally won by Le Gendre, of Georgetown. The 100-yard
low hurdle race was captured by
Hile, of Penn State, in a close finish with Parent, of the Meadowbrook Club. Georgetown again
came to the fore in the 220-yard
dash, when Gaffey broke the tape
ahead of two Virginia men.
In the two middle-distance events
Georgetown and Virginia divided
the honors. Bohannon captured
the 440 for the latter, while Brewster led in the 880. Georgetown
added to her total by grabbing second in both events. Each of these
races started off with a large number of entries and the competition
was exceedingly keen.
One of the features of the evening was the open mile, in which
Connolly, the intercollegiate champion, led Booth, the Hopkins ace,
to the tape by several feet, in 4 min.
30 1-5 secs. Considering the fact
that each of these men had previously run a mile on their respective medley relay team, this time
v.Tas very fast.
The medley relays were the features of the meet, and all were
closely contested. In the first medley of the evening, the Hopkins
team trounced the representatives
of Carnegie Tech. In similar races,
Lafayette downed the University
of Pittsburgh, Georgetown romped
away from Fordham and Penn
State pleased the spectators by
trouncing Navy. In the latter event
Shields was called upon to put
forth his best in order to maintain
his lead over Curtis, of Navy, who
ended with a strong sprint.
One of the closest, fastest and
most exciting races of the evening
was the
.mile relay between Princeton and M. I. T. Tech led for the
first half of the race, but the third
Princeton man made a wonderful
sprint and gave the last man a good
lead. However, the M. I. T. runner started out to catch his man
and at the finish he was only a step
behind Taylor, of Princeton. The
time was 3 min. 28 1-5 secs., the
fastest time for the mile made during the evening.

"THE BLUFFER"
The bottle-fish, one of the most interesting and incredible of
maritime creatures, is the possessor of the rather remarkable ability
proporof voluntarily increasing its size to several times its actual
from
measures
six
maturity,
reaches
it
when
-fish,
tions. The bottle
unasan
is
unmolested,
when
and,
tip,
to
tip
to eight inches from
suming and care-free creature.
But when a larger fish with evil intent approaches, the bottlefish immediately assumes new dimensions. With incredible suddenness, he begins to swell and does not cease until he has attained
an unbelievable size. He is not, only too big to pass through the
jaws of the larger fish, but he is now the aggressor and is able to
terrorize his neighbors by reason of his length and magnitude.
There are many among us who possess this same quality; the
bottle-fish is only demonstrating one of the most common practices
in everyday life-the art of bluffing. Bluff is sometimes condemned
as being deceitful; but, like the bottle-fish, there are many who
would be "devoured" if it were not for a display of strength or
ability beyond their actual powers.
"Bluff," as one of our contemporaries notes, is "but a show of
assumed self-confidence, a camouflaging of weakness. Bluffing and
counter-bluffing put spice and pep into the game of life; commerce,
politics, war, literature, love and countless other phases of life have
their little games of bluff."
"Bluffing" is a good game if played squarely-,without harm to
the "bluffee." It is an admirable and sometimes necessary attribute.
But the individual who goes through college and through life depending upon the art alone, is certainly a misguided person. Bluff
is sure to fail some time; there will surely.come an occasion when
the larger fish will detect the subterfuge of the bottle-fish and will
devour him. Wouldn't it be better to fit ourselves to become a
"larger fish," thus escaping an ever-present peril and ridding oneself
of the necessity of "swelling up."

By C. K. SwARTz, P.H. D.
The years spent in college are
among the most important in a
man's life. They are frought with
influences which mold our future
and lay the foundations of character. To use them wisely is a
worthy ambition in any man. Many
a man has arrived at his senior
year with the sudden discovery
that the years have been illy spent,
the opportunities have flown and
are irrecoverable. It is, hence, a
matter of great moment to answer
the question aright, how can I make
the most of my college course? A
few comments only can be ventured
concerning the more essential conditions of success.
First to be emphasized is the
choice of associates and friends.
Friendships formed in college not
only are among the most delightful
experiences of our college life, but
they affect us as few other influences do in these years. The man
who chooses men of high caliber
and superior character as his
friends can scarcely go astray,
while those who make their associates men of light weight and indifferent qualities cannot confidently hope for true success. To a degree that few of us suspect, we are
influenced
by the judgment,
thought and character of those
about us. The effect of our friends
upon us is as subtle as that of the
air and not less potent. Indeed, our
education springs in no small degree from intercourse with our fellow students, not simply from the
books we read and the men who
teach us. Where our friends are
superior men our minds are quickened by contact with them as diamond polishes diamond. Men of
high worth inspire us to a larger
and truer appreciation of the value
of the finer things of life and stimulate us to attain them, while inferior men sap us of aspirations
for these things. Good friends
bring many rewards.
Sound scholarship is the second
factor to be emphasized. The modern student is surrounded by a host
of things that tend to absorb his
time and withdraw him from the
sursuit of the main thing in college life-sound scholarship. Many
student activities appeal to him for
support. These may be, and doubtless are, in general, of great value
to the student, tending to develop
qualities that will stand him in good
stead in after life. Nevertheless,
they cease to be useful if they stand
in the way of the acquisition of that
for which he should enter college.
Of little use are the appendages
with the central thing left out. The
purpose of the college is the development of sound scholarship.
Upon it all the other features of
the college are built. Executive
ability, social gifts, sound health,
all are to be secured without the
college. Scholarship is developed
within it. The first purpose of the
college is to bring a young man
into contact with the finest thoughts
of the finest minds of the ages, to
impart to him an appreciation of
true values, and to cultivate the
power of independent thought. It
is the possession of these qualities
that make a college man so valuable
a member of the community. No

GOUCHER PROFESSOR ADDRESSES
FIELD CLUB

Lunches, Cigars

Professor Longley, of Goucher
College, delivered a lecture before
the Hopkins Naturalists' Field
Club on Monday, February 20. He
has done much research work on
the fishes in the tropics and he has
a large collection of pictures taken
about the coral reefs at the bottom
of the sea, near the Carnegie Biological Station, at Fort Jefferson,
which is about sixty miles from
Key West.
Professor Longley showed only
pictures, which he photographed,
and he was, therefore, quite able to
explain them interestingly as they
came upon the screen. He showed
the many types of tropical fish, illustrating their habits and characteristics. He, also brought out the
nature of the home of the fishes
among the coral and sea plants.
One particularly interesting feature which Professor Longley
dwelt upon was the ability of many
of these fishes to instantaneously
change their markings and colors
according to their environment.

big Eastern newspapers, one for
the larger state papers, and one for
college publications.
About three hundred form letters
were sent out last week—the
majority going to colleges that
are competing in the games. These
letters enumerated the more important collegiate relays and also the
names of noted athletes who will
be entered in this meet. So far
these letters have been favorably
received and have been published in
a number of papers, including all
of the New York dailies.
It was planned to give the Fifth
Regiment meet especial publicity
in the Washington papers, so that
as many Washingtonians as possible could take advantage of the special cars that ran on Saturday to
attend the games. The fact that
so many Washington schools are
entered shoulll greatly increase the
ihterest.
Much interest is being shown in
the Publicity Board by the students. At a meeting held Monday,
twenty new candidates entered
competition for places on the board.
The enthusiasm of these candidates
was great and excellent results are
expected. .Due to the fact that there
were a large number of Sophomores and Juniors among these
candidates, there will be enough
men of ability to carry on the work
next year.
The board is receiving financial
support from the Varsity Club and
the Student Council. The kindness
of Major Garey and the military
department has made possible much
more extensive work than would
otherwise have been possible. All
o f the copy was typewritten and
mimeographed without expense by
the military department.
As soon as the organization has
been fully completed, it will be possible to extend the range of action
of the board and the results will
become more pronounced.

HOPKINS WINS SOUTH ing in the fifteenth , annual Johns
ATLANTIC MILE RELAY Hopkins-Fifth Regiment Games,
Black and ,Blue Finishes With Wide
with a team which was lacking in
Margin. Medley Team Conquers Carnegie.

In the final event of the evening
the Johns Hopkins mile relay quartet proved that its performance a
week previous at New York was
no flash in the pan, when it triumphed over Virginia and Washing and Lee for the South Atlantic
title. This race was one of the features of the evening, and it came as
a pleasing ending to a program of
stellar track events. The Black
and Blue team was composed of
Thomson, Norwood; Skinner and
Edwards, all of whom had been
kept out of other competition and
primed for their event.
Captain Joe Thompson started
for Hopkins and finished even with
his Virginia man. By fine passing
of the baton, Randy Norwood, running second, managed to grab the
lead on the turn, which he increased to over ten feet before
handing the stick to Bob Skinner.
Bob made a name for himself when
he walked away from the Virginia
man. This he did, not in one sprint,
but by consistent and evenly
timed running. Once he had safely
passed the baton to Ridge Edwards;
the Hopkins rooters relaxed their
tensioned fists, for they knew that
only by a miracle could the latter
be headed. Ridge maintained his
team's lead all the way and if
pushed he could probably have lowered the time considerably. Virginia had second all the way, and
the Generals took third.
The Hopkins medley relay team
also came in for its share of the
glory when it trounced Carnegie
Tech by a wide margin. Clarke
ran first for Hopkins and opened
up a lead that was never increased
/
8 mile grind.
throughout the 17
Dorcus ran the quarter and proved
himself to be another star at that
distance. When he passed the stick
to Sommerville it was with a lead
large enough to foretell the ultimate victory. "Sommy" ran a pretty race and when he gave "Verne"
Booth a lead of about sixty yards
it was just a question of how decisive the victory would be. The
lanky Hopkins miler took things
easy and held the same lead
throughout.
Another feature of the meet,
from a Hopkins standpoint, was
the half-mile interfraternity relay.
This race had stirred up much
friendly rivalry between the different societies and it was a thriller
throughout. First one and then another team flashed into the lead.
Spills were numerous and excitement high at all stages. Marchetti,
anchor man for Kappa Sigma,
finally breezed down the last
straightaway with a comfortable
lead over Middleton, of Alpha Delta Phi. Kappa Alpha finished third.
In the open events only a few
of the Hopkins stars were entered,
most of them being saved for spe-

neither quantity nor quality, easily
captured the team trophy for open
events with a score three times as
great as its nearest competitor, Virginia. With such stars as Le Gendre, Connolly, Kinally, Davis, Shallott, Marsters, Tupar, Brooks,
Gaffey, Brewster, Vokman, Fenney and others, the Washingtonians
presented an array of talent that
was not approached by any other
college.
The shot which started the first
heat of the 100-yard dash was fired
at 7:30, and from that time until
12:20 the track was kept warm almost continuously by the pounding
o; hundreds of feet. After many
preliminaries and semi-finals, this
event was finally won by Le Gendre, of Georgetown. The 100-yard
low hurdle race was captured by
Hile, of Penn State, in a close finish with Parent, of the Meadowbrook Club. Georgetown again
came to the fore in the 220-yard
dash, when Gaffey broke the tape
ahead of two Virginia men.
In the two middle-distance events
Georgetown and Virginia divided
the honors. Bohannon captured
the 440 for the latter, while Brewster led in the 880. Georgetown
added to her total by grabbing second in both events. Each of these
races started off with a large number of entries and the competition
was exceedingly keen.
One of the features of the evening was the open mile, in which
Connolly, the intercollegiate champion, led Booth, the Hopkins ace,
to the tape by several feet, in 4 min.
30 1-5 secs. Considering the fact
that each of these men had previously run a mile on their respective medley relay team, this time
v.Tas very fast.
The medley relays were the features of the meet, and all were
closely contested. In the first medley of the evening, the Hopkins
team trounced the representatives
of Carnegie Tech. In similar races,
Lafayette downed the University
of Pittsburgh, Georgetown romped
away from Fordham and Penn
State pleased the spectators by
trouncing Navy. In the latter event
Shields was called upon to put
forth his best in order to maintain
his lead over Curtis, of Navy, who
ended with a strong sprint.
One of the closest, fastest and
most exciting races of the evening
was the
.mile relay between Princeton and M. I. T. Tech led for the
first half of the race, but the third
Princeton man made a wonderful
sprint and gave the last man a good
lead. However, the M. I. T. runner started out to catch his man
and at the finish he was only a step
behind Taylor, of Princeton. The
time was 3 min. 28 1-5 secs., the
fastest time for the mile made during the evening.

"THE BLUFFER"
The bottle-fish, one of the most interesting and incredible of
maritime creatures, is the possessor of the rather remarkable ability
proporof voluntarily increasing its size to several times its actual
from
measures
six
maturity,
reaches
it
when
-fish,
tions. The bottle
unasan
is
unmolested,
when
and,
tip,
to
tip
to eight inches from
suming and care-free creature.
But when a larger fish with evil intent approaches, the bottlefish immediately assumes new dimensions. With incredible suddenness, he begins to swell and does not cease until he has attained
an unbelievable size. He is not, only too big to pass through the
jaws of the larger fish, but he is now the aggressor and is able to
terrorize his neighbors by reason of his length and magnitude.
There are many among us who possess this same quality; the
bottle-fish is only demonstrating one of the most common practices
in everyday life-the art of bluffing. Bluff is sometimes condemned
as being deceitful; but, like the bottle-fish, there are many who
would be "devoured" if it were not for a display of strength or
ability beyond their actual powers.
"Bluff," as one of our contemporaries notes, is "but a show of
assumed self-confidence, a camouflaging of weakness. Bluffing and
counter-bluffing put spice and pep into the game of life; commerce,
politics, war, literature, love and countless other phases of life have
their little games of bluff."
"Bluffing" is a good game if played squarely-,without harm to
the "bluffee." It is an admirable and sometimes necessary attribute.
But the individual who goes through college and through life depending upon the art alone, is certainly a misguided person. Bluff
is sure to fail some time; there will surely.come an occasion when
the larger fish will detect the subterfuge of the bottle-fish and will
devour him. Wouldn't it be better to fit ourselves to become a
"larger fish," thus escaping an ever-present peril and ridding oneself
of the necessity of "swelling up."

By C. K. SwARTz, P.H. D.
The years spent in college are
among the most important in a
man's life. They are frought with
influences which mold our future
and lay the foundations of character. To use them wisely is a
worthy ambition in any man. Many
a man has arrived at his senior
year with the sudden discovery
that the years have been illy spent,
the opportunities have flown and
are irrecoverable. It is, hence, a
matter of great moment to answer
the question aright, how can I make
the most of my college course? A
few comments only can be ventured
concerning the more essential conditions of success.
First to be emphasized is the
choice of associates and friends.
Friendships formed in college not
only are among the most delightful
experiences of our college life, but
they affect us as few other influences do in these years. The man
who chooses men of high caliber
and superior character as his
friends can scarcely go astray,
while those who make their associates men of light weight and indifferent qualities cannot confidently hope for true success. To a degree that few of us suspect, we are
influenced
by the judgment,
thought and character of those
about us. The effect of our friends
upon us is as subtle as that of the
air and not less potent. Indeed, our
education springs in no small degree from intercourse with our fellow students, not simply from the
books we read and the men who
teach us. Where our friends are
superior men our minds are quickened by contact with them as diamond polishes diamond. Men of
high worth inspire us to a larger
and truer appreciation of the value
of the finer things of life and stimulate us to attain them, while inferior men sap us of aspirations
for these things. Good friends
bring many rewards.
Sound scholarship is the second
factor to be emphasized. The modern student is surrounded by a host
of things that tend to absorb his
time and withdraw him from the
sursuit of the main thing in college life-sound scholarship. Many
student activities appeal to him for
support. These may be, and doubtless are, in general, of great value
to the student, tending to develop
qualities that will stand him in good
stead in after life. Nevertheless,
they cease to be useful if they stand
in the way of the acquisition of that
for which he should enter college.
Of little use are the appendages
with the central thing left out. The
purpose of the college is the development of sound scholarship.
Upon it all the other features of
the college are built. Executive
ability, social gifts, sound health,
all are to be secured without the
college. Scholarship is developed
within it. The first purpose of the
college is to bring a young man
into contact with the finest thoughts
of the finest minds of the ages, to
impart to him an appreciation of
true values, and to cultivate the
power of independent thought. It
is the possession of these qualities
that make a college man so valuable
a member of the community. No
contact with minds of fellow stuContinued on page 3, col. 1

dents can take the place of that
vigorous study, that mastery of
knowledge, that insight into truth
Which are the bases of true scholarship. Especially to be urged is
the study of the things that enrich
the mind and make him a man
among men, not simply the pursuit
of the details of a vocation.
Vigorous health should be
sought. Of little avail is a brilliant mind in a sickly body. The
resources of abounding health will
be demanded in the battle of life.
Fortunate is the man to possess it.
Outdoor life and athletic exercise

in the university.

fellows, genuineness, a deep religious life are qualities that make a
man worthy of esteem and supply
the final test of success in one's
college life.

Lunches, Cigars

Professor Longley, of Goucher
College, delivered a lecture before
the Hopkins Naturalists' Field
Club on Monday, February 20. He
has done much research work on
the fishes in the tropics and he has
a large collection of pictures taken
about the coral reefs at the bottom
of the sea, near the Carnegie Biological Station, at Fort Jefferson,
which is about sixty miles from
Key West.
Professor Longley showed only
pictures, which he photographed,
and he was, therefore, quite able to
explain them interestingly as they
came upon the screen. He showed
the many types of tropical fish, illustrating their habits and characteristics. He, also brought out the
nature of the home of the fishes
among the coral and sea plants.
One particularly interesting feature which Professor Longley
dwelt upon was the ability of many
of these fishes to instantaneously
change their markings and colors
according to their environment.

STUDENT VOLUNTEER CONFERENCE HELD

The Student Volunteer Conference held at Mt. Vernon Place M.
Johns Hopkins News-Letter
E. Church, February 17, 18 and 19,
was a huge success. The Student
Volunteer Movement is composed
of individuals who desire to give
their lives to some branch of foreign missionary service. Hopkins
University has at least two men,
Paul Stevens, '23, and Kennard
Pinder, '24, who are planning for
such work and they were our representatives at this conference.
